por.por_cntn:
The Computer and Information Science and Engineering (CISE) Directorate and its predecessors at the National Science Foundation have played a seminal, but to date, largely untold role in the growth of computing and information research, education, and infrastructure beginning in the 1950s.

In this project, we learned that early NSF actions provided researchers and institutions with large scientific computers and led federal efforts in science information technology and policies. The support for scientific computing has continued to the present and been instrumental in many, major scientific studies. In the 1960s, individual program officers took the initiative to support early theoretical work in computer science and the research needed to create science information technologies as well as other aspects of the emerging field. Spurred by congressional and presidential initiatives, NSF established formal computing and science information programs and offices in the 1970s. Recognition of the value of computing and information research increased research budgets to a point where program staff were able to make investments in networking, cryptography, artificial intelligence, software and systems, and graphics that created new fields of research. With a special focus on experimental computer science in the 1980s, NSF provided computer science departments needed infrastructure and began a series of investments  that would lead from CSNET to NSFNET to the modern internet. Since the mid-1990s, CISE has provided a large majority of all funding for basic research in computer science and closely related disciplines in the United States, as well as substantial support for other fields that study computing or push the state-of-the-art of advanced computation. The results of NSF actions and funding have formed the foundations on which modern computing is built.

The Intellectual Merit of the ''CISE History Project'' is in the collection and organization of a large number of documents relevant to the history of NSF support of computing from 1950 - 2016, a number of new oral histories, a set of chronological narratives that build on that information and other sources, and in a set of case studies that provide more detail on a few key areas. This research resulted in a book currently in publication with ACM Books and a related, publicly available collection of research materials deposited at the Charles Babbage Institute (CBI), an archival unit of the Main Library of the University of Minnesota.

The forthcoming book is comprised of distinct parts that present the results of our work on the project over the past two years. Part 1 provides a narrative of the history of NSF's involvement in the world of digital computing, especially as it relates to the funding activities of CISE and its predecessors. Part 2 goes into more depth on a selected set of important topics. Part 3 provides our conclusions and Part 4 provides various reference information including a description of the archive we have prepared, short biographies, organization charts over time, and abbreviations used.

The Broader Impacts of the CISE History project include the substantial CBI CISE History archive and our forthcoming book, which are resources and sources of open questions for use by computer and information scientists, historians and students of history.  These also serve to provide context and information for NSF staff, potential investigators, department chairs, project managers, and others when entering a role in which they will be dealing frequently with NSF and CISE.
